result.execSummary:
The defendant Logan Joseph Patrick was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess w/Intent-THC (<=200 grams), a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1m)(h)1.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked or will discharge with outstanding financial obligations due, a civil judgment shall be entered for the balance due.

AODA and comply.  6 month periodic review.  Defendant may petition Court in writing, after two years, for expunction of record, contingent upon no new law violations and fine paid in full.  Any bond on hand is to be applied towards costs.

Defendant Logan Joseph Patrick in court with attorney Peter Michael Masana.  Jane E. Kohlwey appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Cases called: 14CF487 & 14CF111.  Rights/Elements. In 14CF111 defendant plead no contest.  Court found guilty.  Judgment was entered.  Court withheld sentencing placed defendant on probation for 2 years.  Conditions of probation include $518.00 costs, AODA and comply.  6 month periodic review.  Defendant may petition Court in writing, after two years, for expunction of record, contingent upon no new law violations and fine paid in full.   In 14CF487 defendant pled no contest to Ct. 2.  Court found guilty.  Judgment was entered.  Ct. 1 dismissed.  Court sentenced defendant to serve 5 days jail 4 days of jail credit, Court considered time served.  $705.00 fines and costs.  Any bond on hand is to be applied towards costs and fine.  60 days to pya or set up a payment plan with Clerk of Courts.
Plea/sentencing hearing on June 17, 2015 at 02:45 pm.
